posts.excerpt: Quote: The 16mm test roll for James Benning’s feature-length film TEN SKIES. 74.78 is part of Mike Plante’s Lunchfilm series of commissioned shorts (made for the cost of a lunch between Plante and filmmaker James Benning).

posts._title: Jean-Guy Noël – Tu brûles… tu brûles… (1973)
posts.title: Tu brûles… tu brûles…
posts.excerpt: A dropout gets the margins of society and resists his father’s pressure to return to the bosom of the village. The film transcends anecdote by diving into a wacky and unusual universe, full of fantasy, imagination, and visual and sound gags.

posts._title: Jean-Luc Godard & Jean-Pierre Gorin – Tout va bien AKA Everything’s All Right [+extras] (1972)
posts.title: Tout va bien
posts.excerpt: The film centers on a strike at a sausage factory which is witnessed by an American reporter and her French husband, who is a director of TV commercials. The film has a strong political message which outlines the logic of the class struggle in France in the wake of the May 1968 civil unrest. It …

posts.title: Elle
posts.excerpt: Quote: Who else but Isabelle Huppert could have played Michèle Leblanc, the eponymous heroine of Paul Verhoeven’s Elle? The exuberant gravitas, the unapologetic condescension, the classily managed aggression that only the most French of faces could ever entertain—Huppert reduces us to our prosaic mortality with a glance, the pursing of her lips, the nearly imperceptible …

posts._title: José Luis Guerín – Le Saphir de Saint-Louis AKA The Sapphire of St. Louis (2015)
posts.title: Le Saphir de Saint-Louis
posts.excerpt: In 1741, a ship called the Saphir sets sail from a port in La Rochelle, France on its way to the New World. On board are thirty crewmembers and two hundred seventy-one slaves. Somewhere off the coast of Santo Domingo, a slave revolt erupts. This little-known moment in history was memorialized in an obscure 18th …

posts._title: Tadeusz Konwicki – Ostatni dzien lata AKA The Last Day of Summer (1958)
posts.title: Ostatni dzien lata
posts.excerpt: Quote: There is something vaguely mythical to the manner in which Konwicki introduces his characters, both to us and to each other, lapped as much by the ethereal eeriness of the score as by the seaside winds that send their hair aflutter. When they tend to speak to each other in whispers, it seems almost …

posts._title: Krzysztof Kieslowski – Dekalog AKA The Decalogue (1989)
posts.title: Dekalog
posts.excerpt: Quote: The Ten Commandments, exact and uncompromising, literally cast in stone, continues to provide a source of moral conflict in contemporary society. In the ten part epic masterpiece, Decalogue, Krzysztof Kieslowski examines the dilemma of fundamental sin in the lives of ordinary Warsaw citizens. A scientist (Henryk Baranowski) puts his faith in science and logic …

posts._title: Michel Brault – Les Ordres AKA Orders (1974)
posts.title: Les Ordres
posts.excerpt: Les ordres has been rated by critics as one of the best Canadian films ever made. It subtly blends fiction and documentary realism in a chilling portrait of what can happen to a liberal democracy when the state imposes its power. posts._title: Robert Wilson – Arvo Part: Adam’s Passion (2015)
posts.title: Arvo Part: Adam’s Passion
posts.excerpt: Adam’s Passion is the moving first collaboration between two “masters of slow motion who harmonize perfectly with each other” (Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung). posts._title: Robert Bresson – Au hasard Balthazar AKA Balthazar (1966)
posts.title: Au hasard Balthazar
posts.excerpt: Quote: Balthazar is a farm animal – a donkey – born into a life of servitude: a beast of burden destined to work the land, carry bales of hay, provide occasional transportation. His harsh, often exploited existence is paralleled through the life of Marie (Anne Wiazemsky), a reticent young woman whose father (Philippe Asselin) has …
